body_text.text: Eine initial eindrucksvolle -mit entsprechender Symptomatik klinisch hochsuspekt auf Malignität hinweisende Raumforderungentpuppt sich als "ein Schaf im Wolfspelz".

Anfang Juni präsentiert sich ein 64-jähriger Patient (188 cm, 123 kg; Nieraucher, keine signifikanten Vorerkrankungen, in der Jugend längere Staubbelastung in der Rosshaarverarbeitung). Seit ca. 5 Wochen besteht eine progrediente Dyspnoe und sowie ausgeprägte B-Symptomatik, unproduktiver Husten sowie Schmerzen in den großen Gelenken (Knie und oberen Sprunggelenk) seit längerem. Ein rezenter Auslandsaufenthalt ist nicht erhebbar, ebenso keine Hautveränderungen. Mitte Mai hatte der Patient eine Pneumonie mit hohem Fieber, welche vom Hausarzt antibiotisch mit Ciproxin behandelt wurde.

Laborchemisch kann h.o. ein gering erhöhtes CRP (15 mg/l) bei sonst blanden Parametern festgestellt werden. Der pulmonale Gasaustausch in Ruhe ergab eine nicht sauerstoffpflichtige respiratorische Partialinsuffizienz, die Lungenfunktion zeigt grenzwertige normale Lungenvolumina ohne Hinweis auf Obstruktion. Im Thoraxübersichtsröntgen imponiert ein deutlich plumper Hilus sowie Erguss links. Das Thorax-CT zeigt ein deutlich links vermindertes Lungenvolumen mit großer zentraler Raumforderung links hilär, zahlreichen vergrößerten mediastinalen Lymphknoten, sowie einem ca. 4 cm hoher Pleuraerguss links (Abbildung).

Anamnese: Ein 35-jähriger Mann wurde aufgrund von beidseitigen Pleuraergüssen an unserer Abteilung vorstellig. Zwei Jahre zuvor war aufgrund von Thoraxschmerzen und Dyspnoe eine thorakale Computertomographie durchgeführt worden. Die dabei aufgefallene Veränderung im vorderen oberen Mediastinum mit zystischen Anteilen wurde zunächst als Mediastinitis interpretiert. In CT-Verlaufskontrollen zeigte sich eine Größenprogredienz. Im Anschluss an eine Mediastinoskopie erfolgte die Exstirpation der Raumforderung mittels partieller Sternotomie. Die histologische Untersuchung ergab einen Thymusrest mit perithymischen Lymphgefäßstrukturen.

Diagnostik: Drei Monate später wurde erstmalig an unserer Abteilung eine Pleurapunktion durchgeführt. Es fand sich ein hämorrhagischer Erguss ohne Keimnachweis. Trotz antiinflammatorischer Therapie waren beidseits wiederholte Drainagen erforderlich. Bei jeweils nüchternem Patienten bestanden niedrige Triglicerid-Spiegel im Punktat, erst nach Provokation mit fettreicher Nahrung konnte ein Chylothorax diagnostiziert werden. Klinisch und radiologisch fielen im Verlauf Osteolysen im Bereich von Sternum, Clavicula und 1.-3. Rippe rechts auf. Dies legte die Verdachtsdiagnose Gorham-Stout-Syndrom nahe, die Bestätigung gelang mittels chirurgischer Weichteil-und Knochenbiopsie, wo sich die charakteristische lymphangiomatöse Proliferation mit Osteolyse zeigte.

Diagnose: Das Gorham-Stout-Syndrom, auch Vanishing bone disease, ist eine seltene Erkrankung charakterisiert durch diffuse Lymphgefäßproliferation begleitet von progressiver Knochenresorption. Die Ätiologie ist unklar. Alle Teile des Skeletts können betroffen sein. Die Symptome sind abhängig von der Lokalisation und können Schmerzen, Schwellungen und pathologische Frakturen umfassen. Bei thorakaler Manifestation kann es zum Auftreten eines Chylothorax kommen, was mit einer hohen Mortalität einhergeht. Betroffen sind vor allem Kinder und junge Erwachsene.

Therapie: Eine konservative Therapie des Chylothorax mit totaler parenteraler Ernährung bzw. einer Diät mit mittelkettigen Fettsäuren zeigte keinen Erfolg. Aufgrund der Seltenheit der Erkrankung ist keine Standardtherapie bekannt. Wie in Fallberichten beschrieben, wurde eine Therapie mit Bisphosphonaten und Calzium-D3 eingeleitet. Im Anschluss an eine thorakale Radiotherapie mit 40 Gy wurden Interferon a und Bevacizumab verabreicht. Bei steigender Frequenz der notwendigen Punktionen war die Anlage eines dauerhaften Pleurakatheters erforderlich. Schließlich wurde eine thorakoskopische Ligatur des Ductus thoracicus angestrebt.

"Postoperativ nicht ganz dicht -untreatable airleak?" M. Humenberger, R. Kropfmüller, J. Demmer, B. body_text.text: Anamnestisch musste der Patient 2013 aufgrund einer schweren Pleuropneumonie linksseitig mit Sepsis maschinell beatmet und intensivmedizinisch betreut werden.

Im November 2013 wurde hinsichtlich eines zu suspizierenden Pleuraempyems DD Tumorverdacht eine 2-malige Thorakotomie durchgeführt, histologisch konnte neben einer abszedierenden und organisierenden Pneumonie kein malignes Geschehen nachgewiesen werden. Im Januar 2015 wurde der Patient mit dem Bild einer "destroyed lung" links an der Thoraxchirurgie des AKH Linz aufgenommen und eine Pneumektomie links an der ECMO durchgeführt. Im weiteren Verlauf wurde im Mai 2015 eine Spätinsuffizienz des Bronchusstumpfes links diagnostiziert, und der Fall wurde uns chirurgischerseits mit der Bitte um endoskopische Sanierung des airleaks, als Alternative zur chirurgischen Intervention, präsentiert.

An Symptomatik zeigen sich zu diesem Zeitpunkt ein chronischer Hustenreiz und eine zunehmende Ruhedyspnoe, begleitet von linksthorakalen Schmerzen. Eine COPD °III-IV ist vorbekannt, eine respiratorische Globalinsuffizienz ist vorliegend.

Nach entsprechender endoskopischer Exploration, und trotz der zentralen Lage des air-leaks im Bronchialsystem wird nach Anamnese: Ein 52-jähriger Patient wird mit dem Notarzt aufgrund von prolongierter Dyspnoe bei vorbekannter COPD ins Spital gebracht. Der Patient steht seit 6 Monaten in regelmäßiger Betreuung beim Lungenfacharzt, dabei ist es zu einem raschen Voranschreiten der spirometrisch gemessenen Obstruktion gekommen, sodass auch eine Mischform im Sinne eines ACOS in Differentialdiagnose genommen wurde. Eine kürzlich durchgeführte kardiologische Abklärung brachte keine wesentlichen Pathologien und der Patient wird bei Verdacht auf infektexazerbierte COPD stationär aufgenommen.

Verlauf: Aufgrund erhöhter Infektparameter und spastischen Atemgeräuschen wird eine Antibiose sowie Exazerbationstherapie begonnen. Dyspnoe-Beschwerden treten vor allem im Liegen auf, außerdem bestehen inspiratorische Nebengeräusche. Ein Trachealkollaps-Syndrom wird suspiziert und die Indikation zur bronchoskopischen Abklärung gestellt. Dabei findet sich ein beinahe die gesamte Zirkumferenz einnehmender polypöser Exophyt im unteren Drittel der Trachea. Dieser kann in toto abgetragen werden, die histologische Auswertung zeigt ein chondromatöses Hamartom. In der Computertomographie des Thorax und Abdomen finden sich keine weiteren Auffälligkeiten. Die Lungenfunktion nach Abtragung zeigt eine unauffällige Fluss-Volumskurve, die Oxygenierung ist im Normbereich, die bisherige "stadiengerechte COPD-Therapie" kann beendet werden. Die Infektparameter und die Klinik einer scheinbaren Exazerbation sind einer poststenotischen Bronchitis zuzuschreiben, die Symptomatik bessert sich rasch und der Patient kann völlig beschwerdefrei entlassen werden.

Schlussfolgerungen: Lungenfunktionell ist eine ungewöhnliche Konfiguration der Fluss-Volums-Kurve ohne Peak oder typischen Emphysemknick erkennbar, wobei jedoch in der Inspirationsphase kein eindeutiges Plateau vorliegt. Die Resistance-Kurve zeigt einen ungewöhnlich, S-förmig imponierenden Verlauf. Aufgrund der gestielten Form des Hamartoms, das an der Vorderwand der distalen Trachea den Ursprung hatte, kam es vor allem im Liegen zu einer hochgradigen Obstruktion des Atemwegs. Zuletzt konnte auch ein inspiratorisches Nebengeräusch erhoben werden. Dies sollte jedenfalls Anlass zur weiteren Abklärung geben.

Hamartome stellen die häufigsten benignen Lungentumore dar. 10 % finden sich endobronchial (und endotracheal), die restlichen 90 % intraparenchymal [1] . Tracheale Hamartome werden selten in der Literatur beschrieben, retrospektiv fanden sich lediglich ca. 20 Fallberichte in der PubMed Database seit 1959, die Inzidenz dürfte jedoch deutlich höher sein. Die Therapieoptionen umfassen waitand-see (bei gesicherter Histologie), chirurgische Sanierung, sowie die in erster Linie empfohlene endoskopische Resektion. Anamnese: 62-jähriger Patient, guter Allgemeinzustand; anamnestisch Diabetes mellitus II mit oraler Therapie, Hepatitis C, arterielle Hypertonie.

Symptome: Zunehmende Belastungsdyspnoe führt zu einem CT-Thorax, in dem sich ausgeprägte mediastinale und hiläre Lymphknoten, sowie auch kleinnoduläre Veränderungen zeigen; abdominell finden sich nur marginal vergrößerte LK. Laborchemisch ist eine Niereninsuffizienz de novo (2,5 mg/dl), sowie auch eine Hypercalciämie (2,9 mmol/l) und ein erhöhter ACE-Spiegel (102 U/ml) auffällig.

Diagnostik, Therapie und Verlauf: Bronchoskopie mit lymphozytärer BAL; typischer CD4/CD8 Ratio. Etablierung einer systemischen Corticoidtherapie 1 mg/kg/KG; nach kurzer Zeit Verbesserung der laborchemischen Parameter (Calcium, Kreatinin, ACE), der primär pathologischen Diffusionskapazität sowie schließlich auch des CT-Thorax im Sinne einer deutlichen Regressio der LK und der nodulären Parenchymveränderungen.

Bei Reduzierung der Cortisontherapie kommt es nach Monaten wieder zur Verschlechterung des Calciumspiegels sowie des Kreatinins, jedoch zu keinem pulmonalen Relapse. Klinisch ist eine progrediente Gewichtsabnahme und Verschlechterung auffällig.
In der CT-Kontrolle erscheinen ausgeprägte retroperitoneale Lymphknoten, sowie auch eine Raumforderung im Bereich der linken Nierenloge, von der Milz nicht abgrenzbar.
Im PET finden sich intensiv speichernde pathologische hypermetabole Herde abdominell mit einem SUV von 25,0, sowie auch inguinal (SUV 21, 3) .
Die Beckenkammbiopsie ergibt keinen Hinweis für eine lymphatische Erkrankung.

Die Histologie eines inguinalen Lymphknotens bestätigt die Diagnose eines diffus großzelligen B-Zell Lymphoms. Der Patient wird mit einem chemotherapeutischem Schema nach R COMP therapiert und ist bei schlechtem Allgemeinzustand bereits seit vier Monaten hospitalisiert.

Zusammenfassung: Ein "klassischer" Fall einer Sarkoidose mit durchwegs kompatiblen Befunden und primär gutem Ansprechen auf Cortison führte letztlich zur Diagnose eines B Zell Lymphoms. Es ist wahrscheinlich, dass es sich um eine sarkoide Reaktion der Lunge im Rahmen der lymphatischen Erkrankung handelt, die sich zum Zeitpunkt der Diagnose zwei Jahre davor weder laborchemisch, noch radiologisch zeigte.
"Die knöcherne Lunge" -Diffuse pulmonale Ossifikation In der Lungenfunktion zeigen sich grenzwertig normale Befunde mit Hinweis auf eine incipiente Diffusionsstörung (siehe Tab. 1).

Die HRCT ergibt das Bild einer diffusen, interstitiellen retikulo-nodulären, teils punktförmig verkalkten Strukturvermehrung, vorwiegend um das bronchovaskuläre Bündel lokalisiert und von apical nach basal zunehmend -kein Milchglas, kein Honeycombing, unauffällige Lymphknoten, keine primär malignomsuspekten Veränderungen.
Differentialdiagnostisch liegt zu diesem Zeitpunkt der Verdacht auf postpneumonische Veränderungen, beispielsweise im Rahmen der früheren Varizellen-Infektion, nahe.

Letztlich liefert die diagnostische Bronchoskopie mit Biopsie aus dem rechten Unterlappen den entscheidenden Hinweis: in der histologischen Aufarbeitung kommt eine Lungengerüstvermehrung mit Knochenbildungsherden im Sinne einer diffusen, dendriformen Ossifikation zur Darstellung. Die zytolog. Aufarbeitung inkl. ZN und spezifischer Kultur aus der BAL ist unauffällig.

Diagnose, Verlauf und Diskussion: Nach sorgfältigem Ausschluss sekundärer Ursachen diffuser pulmonaler Ossifikation wie chronische Lungen-oder Herzerkrankungen mit Druckerhöhung im kleinen Kreislauf, Autoimmunerkrankungen sowie Erkrankungen mit Störungen des Calcium-Phosphatstoffwechsels, wird schließlich eine idiopathische pulmonale Ossifikation diagnostiziert.

Mit weniger als 50 Fallberichten in der weltweiten Literatur, stellt die idiopathische pulmonale Ossifikation ein äußerst seltenes Krankheitsbild dar, das vor allem Männer zwischen 40a und 60a betrifft und meist asymptomatisch bis mild verläuft. Nur in sehr ausgeprägten Fällen wurde lungenfunktionell eine restriktive Störung beschrieben. Die Diagnosestellung ist in vivo mittels HRCT, Lungenbiopsie oder Knochenszintigraphie möglich, zumeist wird die Erkrankung jedoch erst post mortem im Rahmen einer Autopsie als solche erkannt. Histologisch kann zwischen einem dendriformen und einem nodulären Typ unterschieden werden. Die Pathogenese ist nicht geklärt; vermutet werden Störungen im Calciumphosphatstoffwechsel, in der Angiogenese sowie Mikrotraumata. Therapeutisch gibt es keine evidenzbasierte Therapieempfehlung, die Gabe von Corticostereoiden und Biphosphonaten wird kontrovers diskutiert.

Unser Patient zeigt nun seit >10a eine radiologische Befundkonstanz; lungenfunktionell lässt sich eine minimale Befundprogredienz feststellen (siehe Tab. 1). Subjektiv besteht nach wie vor Beschwerdefreiheit und der Patient benötigt keine Therapie.

Background: Thymic Epithelial Tumors (TETs) comprising Thymomas, Thymic Carcinomas (TCs) and thymic neuroendocrine tumors (TNETs) are the most common tumors in the anterior mediastinum in adults. Heat shock proteins (HSPs) functioning as intracellular chaperones and inhibitors of apoptosis are overexpressed in several malignancies and correlated with tumor cell survival and poor clinical outcome. We aimed to investigate the prognostic and clinical relevance of the strongest inducible HSPs (HSP27&70) in serum and tissues specimens of patients with TETs.

Methods: Tissues specimens of 101 TETs were evaluated for HSP27 and 70 expression by immunohistochemistry and correlated with Masaoka Koga Tumor Stage, WHO tumor classification, overall survival (OS) and freedom from recurrence (FFR) rates. Additionally HSP27 and 70 serum concentrations were measured in patients with TETs (n = 46), thymic hyperplasia (TH; n = 33) and volunteers (n = 49). Moreover HSP27 serum levels (n = 16) were evaluated before and after resection.

Results: Strong cytoplasmic HSP27 and nuclear 70 expression was found in all TETs, except TNETs (p < 0.001 and p = 0.003, respectively). The strongest cytoplasmic and nuclear HSP70 expression was found in early tumor stages (Masaoka Koga stage I) and gradually decreased with increasing malignant tumor behavior (p = 0.261 and p = 0.037, respectively). Lowest HSP70 expression was found in metastatic tumors. FFR was significantly worse in TETs with absent or low cytoplasmic HSP27 and nuclear HSP70 expression (p = 0.017 and p = 0.016, respectively). Serum HSP27 and 70 concentrations were increased in patients with TETs (p = 0.040 and p = 0.021, respectively), particularly in patients with TCs (p = 0.027 and p = 0.034, respectively). HSP27 serum concentrations significantly decreased after complete tumor resection (p = 0.015).

Conclusions: TETs generally overexpress HSP, except TNETs. Low HSP expression in tumor specimens was associated with worse FFR. Serum HSP concentrations were elevated in patients with TETs, advanced tumor stages and decreased after complete tumor resection.

Background: Malignant pleural mesothelioma (MPM) is a devastating malignancy with still rising incidence worldwide. Currently, platinum-based chemotherapy in combination with antifolate agents is the standard front-line therapy for MPM and to date no molecularly targeted therapeutic approaches have been approved in the clinics. Nintedanib, an inhibitor of VEGFR, PDGFR and FGFR tyrosine kinase isoforms, is capable to suppress angiogenesis and tumor growth. Here, we report the antitumor activity of nintedanib in MPM.

Methods: IC50 values for nintedanib were determined in 21 MPM cell lines. 4 cell models were selected for further in vitro analysis: proliferation, apoptosis, colony formation and cell migration assays were performed. The downstream signaling of the target receptors was investigated by immunoblotting. Drug interactions with cisplatin were assessed by using the CalcuSyn software. The in vivo anti-MPM activity of nintedanib was studied in an orthotopic human MPM xenograft model in SCID mice.

Results: Nintedanib exerted a growth inhibitory effect on MPM cell lines in both short-and long-term viability assays. The inhibition of proliferation was observed in all MPM cell models, whereas significant apoptosis induction was only found in half of them. Migratory activity strongly decreased upon nintedanib treatment. Down-regulation of Erk1/2 phosphorylation was evident within 10 min of treatment and was present even after 24 h. Nintedanib, however, had no inhibitory effect on the activation of Akt or S6. Additive, but no synergistic effect with cisplatin was detected. In vivo, survival of PO-treated animals showed favorable trend, but not significant benefit (vs. PO control, log-rank test, p = 0.059). However, nintedanib significantly prolonged the survival of mice when it was administered IP (vs. IP control, log-rank test, p = 0.0008).
Conclusions: Our data suggest that nintedanib exerts antitumor activity in MPM both in vitro and in vivo and thus may represent a promising novel therapeutic option in this malignancy.

A randomized, double-blind, cross-over trial of supplemental oxygen for exercise training in normoxemic COPD* Background: Physical exercise training is an evidence-based treatment in COPD and patients' maximal work capacity is strongly associated with COPD mortality. What remains unknown is whether normoxemic COPD patients benefit from supplemental oxygen during exercise training.

Methods: The Salzburg COPD Exercise and Oxygen (SCOPE) study is a randomized, double-blind, controlled, cross-over trial in 29 normoxemic COPD patients (63.5 ± 5.9 years; FEV 1 %pred.: 46.4 ± 8.6). Participants completed two consecutive periods of 6 weeks of endurance and strength training with progressive intensity, which was performed three times/week with either supplemental oxygen or pressurized room-air (10 l/min, via nasal cannula). Each session of ECG-controlled interval cycling lasted 31 min and consisted of warm-up, seven cycles of one-minute intervals at 70-80 % of maximal work capacity alternating with two minutes of active recovery, and cool-down. Thereafter, participants completed eight strength training exercises, performing one set with 8-15 repetitions to failure. Change in maximal work capacity was the primary study endpoint. Secondary outcomes were further parameters of exercise capacity, muscle strength and the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale.

Results: The increase in maximal work capacity was more than twice as high when patients exercised with supplemental oxygen as compared to room-air (+ 0.16 ± 0.02 vs. + 0.07 ± 0.02 Watt/kg; p < 0.001), which was consistent with all other secondary study endpoints related to exercise capacity. The impact of oxygen on work capacity was 39.1 % of the overall training effect, whereas it had no influence on strength gain (e.g. 10-RM latissimus pull-down; p = 0.428) or depression (p = 0.341). For anxiety a trend for a beneficial oxygen effect was observed (−17.48 %; p = 0.084).

Conclusions: We demonstrate for the first time that supplemental oxygen in normoxemic COPD doubles the effect of endurance training, but has no effect on strength gain. A more rapidly increased work capacity might lead to better compliance with training prescriptions, which would thus revolutionize out-patient COPD therapy. Background: Even though the benefits of EVLP with marginal donor lungs have been previously demonstrated, there were no investigations to show if standard donor lungs could benefit of EVLP too. Aim of this study was to investigate the difference in the patient's outcome between cold storage and normothermic ex vivo lung perfusion (EVLP) prior to lung transplantation (LuTX).

Methods: In this prospective randomized single center study two groups of patients were compared to each other. Donor lungs in Group A were subjected to 4 h of normothermic EVLP according to our standard protocol before they were assessed and transplanted. Lungs in Group B were directly transplanted after standard cold storage. Recipient inclusion criteria were: primary LuTX; age > 18j; absence of primary pulmonary hypertension, no preoperative bridging. From October 2013 to Mai 2015, 80 pairs of eligible recipients and their allocated donor lungs were randomized (group A EVLP: n = 39; group B control: n = 41). Within the perfused lungs, decision to transplant was withdrawn during EVLP in 4 cases due to insufficient quality (n = 2), vascular anomalies (n = 1) and iatrogenic damage during retrieval (n = 1), leading to 35 subsequently transplanted lungs.

Results: Recipient and donor demographics were comparable in all means. Post-operative outcomes were comparable in terms of: Intubation time (1.4 vs. 1.6 days; p = 0.67), duration on ICU (6 vs. 6.4 days; p = 0.76) and hospitalization time (21.5 vs. 19 days; p = 0.55). The need for prolonged ECMO after LuTX such as 30d mortality was comparable for both groups (6.3 % vs. 13.9 %//2.9 % vs. 0 %). Neither oxygenation (at Fio2 = 1.0) nor occurrence of primary graft dysfunction (PGD > 1) did differ significantly (T24: 516 vs. 506 mmHG; p = 0.73//T72: 403 vs. 452 mmHG; p = 0.74//3.1 % vs. 2.8 % PGD; p = 0.29).

Conclusions: Short term outcomes were comparable in both groups. EVLP made it possible to safely detect previously unrecognized impairments of the donor lungs. Further, the preservation time was significantly prolonged.
Relationship between health-related quality of life and maximum endurance capacity in respiratory patients*

Background: Psychological well-being influences daily physical activity in patients with COPD [1] . The aim of each rehabilitation center is the improvement of quality of life for the patients. A completed rehabilitation programme, quitting smoking and a balanced diet are factors that improve quality of life in patients with COPD [2] . The Relation between the maximum endurance capacity and the subjective health-related quality of life has not been evaluated yet in respiratory patients.

Methods: 238 subjects with respiratory diseases passed the pretest and 175 of them finished the posttest during an outpatient rehabilitation treatment. To predict health-related quality of life the chronic respiratory questionnaire (CRQ) [3] was used. The maximum endurance capacity was determined during a cycle ergometry with level protocol (Pmax). Furthermore, the difference between the post-to pretest values in CRQ and Pmax was calculated (diff-CRQ bzw. diffPmax: posttest-pretest). Correlations between CRQ and Pmax were calculated in the pre-and posttest values as well as between diffCRQ and diffPmax.

Results: Correlation calculations of the pretest (preCRQ and prePmax) showed a highly significant relationship between maximum physical capacity and subjective quality of life (p < 0.001, r = 0.224). A higher correlation was presented in the posttest (post-CRQ and postPmax) with the same significance (p < 0.001, r = 0.396). In addition the correlations of the difference variable (diffCRQ and diffPmax) were highly significant (p < 0.001, r = 0.320) Conclusions: The maximum endurance capacity shows a highly significant relation with health related quality of life in respiratory patients and vice versa. An increase in the maximum endurance capacity leads to a significantly correlative improvement in quality of life. To summarize, improving the endurance capacity of respiratory patients is not only important for clinical recovery, but also likely affects the subjective well-being in a positive way.

The biological and clinical significance of alpha-1 antitrypsin in non-small cell lung cancer Backgound: The smoking status of physicians can influence the smoking prevalence of the general population. Many patients see their doctor as a role model for a healthy life style. Physicians, who smoke themselves, are less likely to recommend cessation programs to their patients. The intention of this survey was to analyze for the first time, whether there is a difference between the smoking habits of Austrian's physicians and the general population.

Methods: A random sample of all practicing physicians was drawn in each province, stratified for specialty. From each specialty at least 10 % were surveyed by standardized telephone interview. Sensitivity analyses were performed for non-responders. Results were compared with the smoking status in the general population of the province (Health Interview Survey by Statistics Austria), adjusted for sex and age.

Results: The response rate in the 9 counties varied from 99 % (K, N, St, T, V, W) to 100 % (B, O, S). Non-smokers ranged from 84 % (B, W) to 94 % (S), consisting of never-smokers (B 48 %, K 70 %) and exsmokers (K 21 %, B 36 %).The quit rate was lowest in V (59 %) and highest in T (74 %). Current smokers ranged from 9 % (K, S, T) to 16 % (B, W). In all 9 provinces physicians smoked less than the general population corresponding in age and sex (expected smoking rates from 20 % in St to 35 in O). Except for B the differences between the smoking rates of physicians and the expected smoking rates in the age/sex-corresponding population was statistically significant. The lowest smoking rates were found in pneumologists and the highest in surgeons.

Conclusions: Even though the smoking prevalence of Austrian physicians is lower compared to physicians in Southern Europe, there is still a huge potential to decrease smoking prevalence in order to optimize the consultation of smoking patients.

Denoising algorithm for quantitative assessment of thoracic dual-energy computed tomography images Background: Dual-energy computed tomography (DE-CT) allows the visualization of perfusion defects in the lung and can therefore aid the diagnosis of acute or chronic pulmonary embolism. However, the contrast-to-noise ratio of the scanner-provided images is too low for quantitative analysis of contrast material concentrations in the lung parenchyma.

Methods: We applied a 3D total generalized variation algorithm to denoise DE-CT images acquired with a Siemens Somatom Definition Flash scanner. The two X-ray source/detector systems were set to 100 kV/91 mAs and 140 kV/77 mAs with a 0.4 mm tin filter, respectively. For validation of the algorithm we used either images from a phantom experiment (Falcon tubes filled with different concentrations of iodine) or dynamic CT images of contras-material bolus propagation in 20 patients underwent thoracic CT examination.

Results: The algorithm denoised the images while preserving the anatomical information. Iodine concentrations determined with our algorithm and actual concentrations in the samples of the phantom experiment showed a linear correlation with a slope of 1 (R 2 = 0.983) within the physiologic range of iodine between 0 and 20 mg/mL. The contrast-to-noise ratio was improved to values above 5 even in the low-concentration range (3.7 mg/mL). This allows reliable quantification of the expected iodine concentrations in the lung parenchyma, too. Dynamic CT images showed that X-ray attenuation values were not affected by the algorithm and, therefore, lead to almost identical results between the original and denoised datasets. This was further confirmed by assessing secondary parameters from the dynamic CT, like the cardiac output (Bland-Altmann test: difference − 0.03 L/min with confidence intervals: [− 0.37, 0.31] L/min).

Conclusions: 3D denoising with the total generalized variation algorithm increases contrast-to-noise ratio while preserving anatomic structures and X-ray attenuation values. Therefore, this algorithm is suitable for the quantification of perfusion in thoracic dual-energy CT images. Validating the algorithm in a clinical setting of lung disease diagnosis is warranted. Background: Sepsis has a higher mortality than lung or breast cancer [1] . One of the most important etiologic factors is pneumonia [2] . Increasingly, social media play an important role to promote scientific work. To date, approximately one in four physicians uses social media to stay up-to-date on medical innovations and information [3] . However, scientific papers with a high impact in the social media may not necessarily represent high scientific quality but entertainment, controversity or abstrusity [4] such as studies on chocolate, weight loss or sexual activities.

Methods: Quantitative data about twelve important studies was collected. We compared four studies about early-goal directed therapy (EGDT) in sepsis with eight alternative major ICU studies analysing Twitter, Altmetrics, ResearchGate, Google Scholar and Web of Science.

Results: Sepsis studies had a higher social media representation in comparison to the other ICU studies. The ProCESS study (2014) had the highest Altmetrics score of all examined studies. The ARISE study (2014) even has a Twitter Account. Although the original EGDT trial [5] has been published fourteen years ago, it had an above average Altmetrics score (orginial EGDT = 176 vs average = 80.42). Interestingly, the Altmetric Score neither correlated with Google Citations (r = -0.001, p = 0.998) nor publishing date (r = 0.022, p = 0.945).

Conclusions: We show that major sepsis studies have a high impact in the social media. Beyond Warburg effect: Adaptation to low glucose involves use of glutamine as alternative carbon source in lung cancer cells Background: Cancer cell adaptation to glucose deprivation, although frequently present in solid cancers, is poorly understood. Gluconeogenesis, the generation of glucose from small carbon substrates, is an important metabolic pathway in liver cells. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK) is the key enzyme for gluconeogenesis, and abbreviated pathways like glyceroneogenesis (generation of glycerol). We have shown that PEPCK (PCK2) is up-regulated in nonsmall cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cells under low glucose conditions. The aim of this study was to analyze, whether glutamine is a precursor for the gluconeogenesis pathway in lung cancer cells.

Methods: Expression of glutamine transporters and PCK2 was measured by quantitative PCR (qPCR). Conversion of uniformly 13 C-labeled glutamine or uniformly 13 C-labeled lactate to the PEPCK product 13 C 3 -phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) was measured using liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry.

Results: The glutamine transporters SLC1A5 and SLC7A1 were up-regulated along with PCK2 in A549 lung cancer cells under low glucose conditions. Likewise, SLC1A5 and SLC7A1 expression positively correlated with PCK2 in a publically available dataset involving 967 cancer cell lines. In A549 lung cancer cells cultured under low glucose (1 mM), stable isotope labeled glutamine was converted to PEP. The accumulation of labeled PEP was significantly inhibited in the presence of the PEPCK inhibitor 3-MP was significantly higher under low glucose conditions as compared to high glucose conditions. The maximal ratio labeled/unlabeled PEP (app. 0.17) was observed at 0.2 mM glucose indicating that besides glutamine other carbon sources contribute to PEP, either from glycolysis, or gluconeogenesis. In fact, lactate carbons contributed to the PEP pool.

Conclusions: These results suggest that glutamine is converted to PEP via PEPCK under low glucose conditions in lung cancer cells. Glutamine thus may serve as an alternative carbon source in lung cancer cells in a glucose-deprived microenvironment to fuel biosynthetic reactions usually fed by glycolytic intermediates.

Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction and cytokine changes in non-professional marathon runners Background: Exercise is the most common trigger of bronchospasm. If exercise is the only identifiable trigger for the bronchoconstriction, it is called exercise induced bronchoconstriction (EIB), with an estimated prevalence of 8-20 % in the non-asthmatic population. We sought to investigate cytokine changes in non-professional marathon and half marathoners with and without EIB.

Methods: We enrolled 34 probands running a marathon (M), 36 running a half-marathon (HM) and 30 sedentary subjects without asthma. We employed immunosorbent assays to determine the serum concentration of heat shock protein (HSP) 70 and performed blood count analysis before the marathon (prerun), immediately post-marathon at the finish area (immediately after), and 2-7 days after the marathon (recovery). A spirometry was performed by a portable lung function testing device to assess FVC %, FEV1 % and the FEV1/FVC ratio.

Results: We found signs of EIB, defined as a decrease of ≥ 10 % in FEV1 from baseline, in 12 (35.29 %) marathon and 8 (22.22 %) half marathon runners. Among athletes with EIB, 11/20 (55 %) were male and 9/20 (45 %) were female. After distributing runners in a group with EIB and without EIB, we found significantly higher HSP70 serum concentrations in runners with EIB on the day before the competition (p = 0.014). After analyzing marathoners and half marathoners separately, we found significantly increased WBC in marathoners suffering from EIB before participating in the competition (p = 0.021). Immediately after the race we couldn't detect any cytokine changes between runners with and without EIB. After 2-7 days of recovery we found significantly increased HSP70 serum concentrations (p = 0.032), WBC (p = 0.048) and PLT (p = 0.040) in marathoners with EIB, when compared to marathoners without EIB.
Conclusions: We found a higher than expected number of nonprofessional athletes with EIB. HSP70 serum concentrations and elevated WBC could indicate a predisposition to EIB.

Histone deacetylase inhibitor panobinostat reduces hypoxia-induced cisplatin resistance of non-small cell lung carcinoma cells via HIF-1a destabilization Background: Lung cancer is one of the most frequent cancer types and the leading cause of cancer death worldwide. Cisplatin is a widely used chemotherapeutic for non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC), however, its positive effects are diminished under hypoxia. We wanted to determine if co-treatment with cisplatin and histone deacetalyse (HDAC) inhibitor panobinostat can reduce hypoxia-induced cisplatin resistance in NSCLC cells, and to elucidate mechanism involved. Methods: Expression status of different HDACS was determined in two cell lines and in tumor tissue from 20 patients. Cells were treated with cisplatin, panobinostat, or with combination of both under normoxic and hypoxic (1 % O 2 ) conditions. Cell cycle, viability, acetylation of histones, and activation of apoptosis were determined. Human primary, non-malignant bronchial epithelial (BE) cells were used as a control. HIF-1a stability was analyzed by immunoblotting and its interaction with HDAC4 was determined by in vitro proximity ligation.

Results: Most class I and II HDACs were expressed in NSCLC cells and tumor samples. Panobinostat inhibited proliferation of tumor cells under normoxic and hypoxic conditions. Co-treatment of tumor cells with cisplatin and panobinostat decreased cell viability and increased apoptosis more efficiently than in primary, nonmalignant bronchial epithelial cells. Co-treatment induced apoptosis by causing chromatin fragmentation, activation of caspases-3 and 7 and PARP cleavage. Toxic effects were more pronounced under hypoxic conditions. Co-treatment inhibited growth of multicellular-spheroids, where hypoxic conditions develop spontaneously because of limited oxygen diffusion. Co-treatment resulted in destabilization and degradation of HIF-1a and HDAC4, a protein responsible for acetylation and de/stabilization of HIF-1a. Direct interaction between HDAC4 and HIF-1a proteins in H23 cells was detected.

Conclusions: Here we show that hypoxia-induced cisplatin resistance can be overcome by combining cisplatin with panobinostat, a potent HDAC inhibitor. These findings may contribute to the development of a new therapeutic strategy for NSCLC.

Activin A is novel circulating biomarker in small cell lung cancer Background: Identification of biomarkers is urgently needed to facilitate the early detection of small cell lung cancer (SCLC) and predicting patients' responsiveness to different therapeutical strat-egies. Expressions of the growth factor Activin A, and its binding protein, follistatin, are deregulated in a number of malignancies. However, to date there is no data on circulating actvin A and follistatin levels in SCLC.

Methods: Activin A and follistatin plasma levels (PLs) of SCLC patients (n = 79) were analyzed with ELISA. Plasma samples from age-and sex-matched individuals without malignancies served as controls (n = 45). Activin A expressions of primary tumor tissues (n = 42) were analyzed by immunhistochemistry. In vitro Activin A levels of SCLC cell lines (n = 9) were measured with ELISA.

Results: Activin A and follistatin PLs were significantly elevated in patients with SCLC. A significant T-, N-and M-stage-dependent increase in the PLs of activin A, but not of follistatin, was observed. Increased PLs of activin A, but not of follistatin, were associated with significantly shorter overall survival. Furthermore, multivariate analysis revealed that Activin A PL is an independent negative prognostic factor in SCLC patients. Although secretion of activin A was observed in SCLC cell lines in vitro, Activin A protein expressions of the primary tumor tissues did not correlate with the PLs, suggesting that the primary tumor is not the main source of circulating Activin A in SCLC patients.

Conclusions: Our findings suggest that PLs of Activin A and follistatin are elevated in SCLC patients. Moreover, the measurement of circulating activin A can support the diagnosis, staging and prognosis of the disease.

body_text.text: Increased expression of NPY1R mediates increased vascular reactivity to NPY Methods: Expression of NPY and Y1 receptor were determined by quantitative PCR. Cellular response to NPY stimulation was assessed by Western blotting, thymidine incorporation, calcium imaging and cAMP determination. Vascular reactivity measurements were performed using isolated murine pulmonary arteries from normoxic and chronic hypoxic animals. Selective Y1 receptor antagonist and Y1 knockout mice were used to assess the contribution of receptor subtype in mediating NPY effects.

Results: Pulmonary arteries from IPAH patients have increased number of NPYergic axonal endings and increased expression of NPY Y1 receptor (NPY1R). Increased NPY1R expression was also observed in animal PH models (chronic hypoxia exposed mice, monocrotaline treated rats, Sugen-chronic hypoxia exposed rats). NPY increased intracellular calcium levels, enhanced vasoconstriction of pulmonary arteries preconstricted with adrenaline and stimulated proliferation of human pulmonary arterial smooth muscle cells (hPASMC). Additionally, NPY reduced iloprost-induced cAMP increase in human PASMC (30 ± 15 %, p < 0.05). Y1 receptor antagonist, BIBO 3304, inhibited vasoconstrictive and proliferative effects of NPY (1.13 ± 0.08 vs. 0.95 ± 0.11 relative thymidine incorporation, NPY vs. BIBO 3304, respectively). Finally, pulmonary arteries isolated from mice exposed to chronic hypoxia showed stronger NPYinduced vasoconstriction (1.08 ± 0.44 vs.0.55 ± 0.21 mN, p < 0.05, hypoxia vs. normoxia, respectively).

Conclusions: NPY1R is a necessary and sufficient receptor subtype in mediating NPY's induction of two key pathogenic hallmarks of PH. Furthermore, results indicate that increased NPY1R expression could mediate increased hypersensitivity to NPY. Bactericidal activity of N-chlorotaurine against Chlamydia pneumoniae and Chlamydia trachomatis ÖGP Chlamydia pneumoniae causes infections of both the lower and upper respiratory tract, such as pneumonia, bronchitis, pharyngitis and sinusitis. In the last few years, it has also been implicated as an infectious trigger for acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD.

N-chlorotaurine is a mild endogenous long-lived oxidant, which is thought to exert immune-regulatory and antimicrobial properties during inflammation. It has broad-spectrum bactericidal, fungicidal, virucidal, and protozoocidal activity. NCT proved to be very well tolerated by human tissue and can be used topically at different body sites to treat infections, e.g. in the human eye, on the skin, in the ear and paranasal sinuses, in the oral cavity, and in the urinary tract.

NCT caused a concentration-and time-dependent inactivation of C. pneumonia. In chlamydiae treated with 1 % (55 mM) NCT and 0.1 % NCT for 1, 30 or 60 min, or 70 % ethanol for 3 min (positive control), no planar inclusions could be found, indicating loss of chlamydial replication. Lowering the concentration of NCT to 0.01 % resulted in chlamydial growth similar to the controls after 1 and 30 min, while planar inclusions disappeared completely after 60 min incubation time.
Prolonged incubation of the inoculated cells for 144 h did not change this result.

In experiments with second passage infection after lysis of the host cells hardly any fluorescent IFU could be detected when using lysates from NCT treated cells, whereas in controls an overwhelming infection was seen. Thus, the absence of infectivity of the scarce chlamydial inclusions was confirmed implicating bactericidal activity of NCT against C. pneumoniae.

These results were also confirmed by RT-PCR where full chlamydial DNA-replication was found in controls to a high extent, whereas in samples incubated in 0.1 and 1 % NCT relatively low numbers of chlamydial copies were detected. These effects were similar for second passage progeny.
NCT at concentrations of 0.1 and 1 % completely inactivated also C. trachomatis serovars A and D after a minimal incubation time of 1 min. 0.01 % NCT for up to 30 min had no effect.
N-chlorotaurine is chlamydiacidal and might become a promising candidate to treat chlamydial infections via topical application including inhalation.

Cartilage oligomeric matrix protein (COMP) as an adaptive mechanisms to the pressure overload in the right ventricle Background: Right ventricle (RV) is subjected to pressure overload in many clinical situations like pulmonary embolization and pulmonary arterial hypertension. RV functional status predicts survival of those patients. However, the mechanisms of RV adaptation to pressure overload are poorly understood. The aim of our study was to investigate the function of COMP in the RV pressure overload model.

Methods: RV pressure overload was induced in wild-type (WT) or COMP knockout (KO) mice by pulmonary artery band-ing (PAB). Three weeks post-operation, mice were investigated by echocardiography and invasive hemodynamics. Subsequently, histology and gene expression analysis were performed on RV tissue samples.

Results: PAB generated a significant pressure overload in W T mice (RV systolic pressure (RVSP) in PAB = 48 ± 11 mm Hg vs. sham 29 ± 5 mm Hg, p = 0.001). Echocardiography showed thickened RV free wall, enlarged RV and reduced cardiac. Invasive hemodynamics revealed reduced contractility index, prolonged tau, and elevated EDP. Elevated expression of ANP, BNP and collagens was measured in RV tissue samples. Histologic examination revealed RV fibrosis. Elevated COMP expression was detected in RV tissue, which was localized to vimentin and DDR2 positive cells. PAB operation in COMP KO mice caused RVSP elevation comparable with RVSP in WT mice (COMP KO RVSP = 50 ± 4 mm Hg, p = 0.15 vs. WT PAB). However, COMP KO mice demonstrated worse survival after PAB operation. They demonstrated worsening of diastolic function compared to WT mice as evidenced by prolonged Tau (p = 0.012 vs. WT PAB) and elevated RV EDP (p = 0.005 vs WT PAB). Higher degree of RV fibrosis was revealed by Masson's Trichrome staining in RV of COMP KO PAB operated mice.

Conclusions: RV in pressure overload model is characterized by systolic and diastolic dysfunction. Absence of COMP led to worse survival, deterioration of RV diastolic function and more pronounced RV fibrosis. Thus, COMP appears as an adaptive mechanism to pressure overload.

The aim of the current study was to analyse lung function changes of this novel technique in routine clinical practice since the introduction of real-time assessment of collateral ventilation.

Methods: Multicentre, retrospective, case-series of patients with severe symptomatic emphysema despite optimal medical management and at least one follow-up visit after treatment. Pulmonary arterial tortuosity as a non-invasive diagnostic tool for pulmonary arterial hypertension Background: Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is a chronic disorder of the pulmonary circulation, marked by an elevated vascular resistance and pressure. We hypothesized that, patients with increased pressure in the pulmonary arteries will have increased arterial tortuosity.

Methods: We present an automatic pulmonary vessel tree extraction algorithm, which uses contrast-enhanced thoracic CT images as input and identifies individual arterial or venous vessel trees. A vessel enhancement filter was used to find vertices along the vessel centrelines in the lung, which were connected to vessel trees using an integer program. Finally, the automatic vessel labeling is performed based on anatomical measures. We used datasets of patients, without comorbidities, who underwent right heart catheterization and thoracic CT examination. The tortuosity was calculated for each vessel segment and its mean value was compared to the patient's diagnosis and clinical data.

Results: Nineteen patients (5 without, 14 with PH) were analyzed retrospectively. There was no difference in the detected number of vessel segments between the two groups. Comparing patients with and without PH, in the arteries we found a slightly higher difference in the mean tortuosity (PH: 1.037 vs. noPH: 1.028, p = 0.018) than in all the vessels (PH: 1.036 vs. noPH: 1.029, p = 0.008) or in the veins (PH: 1.034 vs. noPH: 1.029, p = 0.008). The tortuosity of the arteries positively correlated with mean pulmonary arterial pressure (r art = 0.74). This was similar to the correlation when all the vessels were considered (r all = 0.75), whereas the veins showed a modest correlation of r veins = 0.58. ROC analysis showed a good power for the arterial tortuosity to discriminate patients with and without PH (Area under the curve: 0.87).

Our fully automatic algorithm provides quantitative readouts of the individual vessel types from thoracic CT images. The power of the arterial tortuosity measure to identify the presence of PH provides a possible tool to non-invasively diagnose pulmonary hypertension.

Clinical value of component-based diagnosis in pollen-allergic patients Background: Component-resolved analysis has gained importance especially in the diagnosis of food-allergies. However it is not clear if specific components can also improve diagnosis of pollenallergies or help in the decision to start specific immunotherapy (SIT).

We retrospectively evaluated patients that were referred to the Allergy Center Vienna West for suspected grass, birch, ragweed, and/or mugwort allergy and were tested for extracts as well as the respective components (Phl p 1, 5, 7; Bet v1, 2, 4; Art v1, 3 and Amb a1) measured by ImmunoCAP. Pearson-Correlation-Coefficients (CC) were calculated between extracts and main components and patients were analyzed on an individual level to see whether component analysis gave additional information for clinical decisions.

Results: We found a high correlation between birch-extract and Bet v1 (CC = 0.89, p < 0.0001) as well as between grass extract and Phl p1,5 (CC = 0.91, p < 0.0001). Positive extract-results and negative component-results (Bet v1 and Phl p1,5) were only relevant for 1 respective patient, where SIT was not recommended. Concerning mugwort-and ragweed allergic patients we found high rates of double-sensitization (41.2 %) against both weeds. Analyzing this group using component analyses we could see, that only 1/3rd of these patients had a real double-allergy against mugwort and ragweed (Amb a1 pos./Art v1 pos.), while about 1/2 was only ragweed allergic (Amb a1pos./Art v1 neg.) and 1/5th only mugwort allergic (Amb a1 neg./Art v1 pos.). This was relevant for the decision of SIT in 15 % of suspected mugwort-allergic and 10 % of suspected ragweed-allergic patients.

Conclusions: In a clinical setting, component resolved diagnosis was important for a significant number of patients with suspected mugwort-and/or ragweed-allergy. In patients suspected for grass or birch-allergy, components did not seem to give additional information in our patients' group.

Extrapleural pneumonectomy with or without a trimodality treatment regime for malignant pleural mesothelioma: a retrospective cohort study in a high volume center Background: Malignant pleural mesothelioma (MPM) is an aggressive thoracic tumor with dismal outcome. Macroscopic complete resection within a multimodality protocol is indicated in patients being fit for surgery. Aim of this study was to investigate short-and long-term outcome of MPM patients undergoing extrapleural pneumonectomy (EPP) within a trimodality treatment (TMT) protocol (induction chemotherapy (CHT), EPP and postoperative intensity modulated radiotherapy (IMRT)) or within other treatment regimens.
Methods: A retrospective review of a prospective database of 101 patients undergoing EPP within different treatment modalities between 1994 and 2015 at our institutions was conducted.

Results: 73 males and 28 females with a mean age of 64 ± 11.9 years at the time of diagnosis were included. 38 patients underwent EPP within TMT, 43 patients within other multimodality regimens and 20 patients EPP alone. Main histological subtype was epitheloid (n = 77; 76 %). Postoperative complication rate was 41 %. 30-day mortality was 5.9 % (n = 6) and 90-day mortality was 14.9 % (n = 15). Mean progression free survival (PFS) was 17.8 months (95 % confidence interval (CI) 10.6-25). Overall 3-and 5-year survival rates were 36 % and 31 %, respectively. 5-year survival was significantly better in patients with EPP within TMT (60 %) compared to patients with EPP within other multimodality regimens (23 %; p = 0.047) and EPP alone (13 %, p = 0.01). In the multivariate survival analysis, type of treatment modality (EPP within TMT vs. rest, p = 0.011) and age (≥ 65 years, p = 0.028) were found to be independent prognostic factors for survival.

Conclusions: EPP within a trimodality protocol is a feasible treatment option with good short and long term outcome. EPP alone offers dismal survival and should be avoided. Backgound: Pulmonary metastasectomy with curative intent is nowadays an essential part in the interdisciplinary treatment of patients with pulmonary spreading. However, most of the available literature is based on retrospective analyses. In order to improve data quality in the field of pulmonary metastasectomy, we established a computer-based, prospective database in our department. All included patients were followed-up by a dedicated team.

Methods: All patients receiving pulmonary metastasectomy with curative intent between 2009-2014 were included in the database and regularly followed-up. More than 300 parameters were recorded for every patient. Complete data sets are available for more than 95 % of patients.

Results: To date 271 patients were included in the database. In this patient cohort, colorectal cancer patients account for the majority of cases (25 %), followed by osteosarcoma (10 %) and renal cell cancer patients (10 %). Mean disease-free survival (time from diagnosis of the primary to pulmonary spreading) was 54.3 months. Single-stage laryngotracheal reconstruction in adults without prolonged postoperative stenting The standard technique for subglottic stenosis is a classical cricotracheal resection, first introduced by Grillo and colleagues. Although it is considered a challenging procedure, it is associated with excellent long-term results. However, a high number of failures is reported in the literature when the stenosis is characterized by an advanced side-to-side narrowing and reaches the level of the vocal cords. For these kind of stenoses laryngotracheal reconstructions (LTR) using cartilage interpositions have to be performed. This technique usually requires a prolonged postoperative stabilization of the reconstructed airway with a stent. Herein, we report our first experience of a modified LTR without the need of a prolonged postoperative stenting.

Methods and results: From 2012-2015 five consecutive cases of laryngotracheal stenosis were surgically corrected by the Laryngotracheal Team Vienna. All patients suffered from a combination of pronounced submucosal thickening and an advanced side-to-side narrowing extending to the level of the vocal fold. Thus, a sufficient lumen enlargement could not be achieved by a standard CTR. In all cases the cricoid plate was completely split in the midline and a rib cartilage was introduced in order to enlarge the subglottic diameter. In contrast to the originally described technique of Couraud et al., the lateral edges of the cartilage graft were trimmed in a stepwise fashion. This led to a completely stable positioning of the graft within the split cricoid. Since the laryngotracheal reconstruction was firm without any instability or collapse, no stent was needed for postoperative stabilization. The perioperative course was uneventful and all patients and the functional outcome was excellent with a normal ventilation, swallowing and voice function 3 months after the operation.
Conclusions: We therefore conclude that by our proposed modifications, LTR can be performed safely without the need of postoperative stenting of the reconstructed airway.

Long-term survival and clinical course after single lung transplantation for interstitial lung disease Background: Interstitial lung disease (ILD) is one of the leading causes for lung transplantation (LuTX). Both, Single (SLuTX) and Double (D) LuTX are well established surgical procedures but new data indicate a tendency to favour the latter. Due to a lack of longtime follow-up data, the aim of our study was to evaluate the clinical course in SLuTX for ILD using our single-center data base.

The study was planned as a single-centre, retrospective analysis of 25 patients with histological confirmed UIP (15) or interstitial fibrotic disorders of other reasons (10) who received single-lung transplantation in our centre between 2003 and 2012. The complications analysed using patient charts. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) scans pre and post transplant were compared and correlated with lung function parameters over the follow-up period. Statistics were performed using SPSS V 22.0.0.0 Results: The mean survival of patients after single-lung transplantation was 79.87 ± 8.29 months. Acute rejection (> A2) occurred in 9 of 22 patients (38.5 %) who survived more than 1 year after transplantation and lymphcytic bronchiolitis (> B2) in 7 patients (31.82 %). Severe infections (n = 9; 40.91 %) were associated with either pneumonectomy (n = 4; 2 aspergilloma), re-transplantation (n = 1) or death (n = 4).

Malignant diseases were diagnosed in a total of 6 patients (27.27 %) with a median onset of 56 ± 29.83 months. Lung cancer was detected in 3 patients (squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)). Malignancy resulted in a mean survival of 68.74 ± 10.96 months after LuTX, which was statistically significant lower than the survival of patient without malignoma (p = 0.025).
Conclusions: The data provided here suggest that SLuTX might be an appropriate surgical strategy in selected patients suffering from interstitial lung disease.

Background: Sleep related breathing disorders (SRBD) and their cardiovascular consequences have been described in several studies. There is strong evidence of a positive relationship between SRBD and hypertension, stroke and heart failure. A fever studies have been published to evaluate the prevalence of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular risk factors in the co-appearance of SRBD.

Methods: We analyzed medical records of our patients for diabetes type 2, hypertension and SRBD measured with standard 5-channel polygraphy. In addition we evaluated patient's medical history for heart failure, atrial fibrillation, amount of antihypertensive drugs, body mass index, HbA1c% and apnoea-hypopnoea index (AHI).

Results: 127 patients underwent polygraphic sleep testing in the last 12 months in the department of internal medicine. 71 (39 male/32 female) suffered from diabetes type 2 and/or hypertension, respectively. 29 patients had type 2 diabetes with an HbA1c greater than 6.5 %, were treated with 3 or more antihypertensive drugs and were concomitantly obese with a BMI greater than 29 kg/m 2 . 26 of those 29 patients (90 %) were diagnosed with a SRBD (mean AHI 26/h).

Conclusions: The high prevalence of SRBD in hypertensive, obese patients and those resistant to antihypertensive therapy and requiring intensive diabetes therapy highlights the need for effective screening and diagnosis of SRBD in this special patient population.

Nach wenigen Tagen des Rehab-Aufenthaltes kommt es erneut zur akuten klinischen Verschlechterung mit Zeichen der Hypoxämie und Lungeninfiltraten und wiederum Überweisung an unsere Klinik.Nun wurde dem Verdacht einer Lungenbeteiligung bei rheumatologischer Grunderkrankung nachgegangen und bei der Patientin ein Antisynthetase-Syndrom (Anti-Jo-1-Auto-AK pos.) mit Polymyositis und pulmonaler Beteiligung diagnostiziert. Nach Steigerung der Steroidmedikation kommt es wiederum zu klinischen Besserung der Patientin. In weiterer Folge wiederholte ambulante Begutachtungen und Einstellung auf unterschiedliche Immunsuppressiva. Zurzeit ist die Patientin unter einer Therapie mit Mycophenolat-Mofetil und Aprednisolon klinisch stabil.Im Retrospekt ist anzunehmen, dass bereits die intensivpflichtige, fulminante Pneumonie mit nachfolgendem ARDS die erste Manifestation des Antisynthetase-Syndroms war.

back_matter.text: Background: A lung cancer database is mandatory for the reflection of the own patient population, planning studies, evaluation of therapeutic interventions and quality control. We continued our work of 2013 by including all newly diagnosed lung cancer patients in our patient-customized database for 2014.Methods: Date of diagnosis, age, gender, family history, topography (C34.×), morphology (ICD-O), staging (pTNM or cTNM by TNM-7), smoking status, lung function parameters and Karnovsky index were recorded. In addition to this, data on therapy and outcome were included with special focus on EGFR-, ALK-and ROS1 status. In the analyses, special attention was dedicated to the cohort of neversmokers with lung cancer.Results: In 2014, 153 patients were included in the database (C34.0-C34.9), of which 97 are male and 56 female. Age at time of diagnosis ranged from 28 to 89 years, mean age was 67 years. An important aspect of the analysis of 2014 was the concordance with the data of 2013. Both, sex ratio, but also the distribution concerning age, stage and histological classification showed a surprisingly clear reproducibility compared to the year 2013.The data, matched with the smoking status, confirmed a number of previously clinically suspected correlations. On the one hand, neversmokers showed an almost dichotomous sharing with regard to the stage distribution (IA vs. IV). On the other hand, the distribution in the bronchial system was significantly different than in former smokers or current smokers with a clear trend towards increasingly peripheral tumors, especially of the lower lobe (47 % vs. 33 %/31 %).Regarding EGFR and ALK status, we were surprised that-despite reflex testing in a significant proportion of patients (25 % each)-no mutation status was present for various reasons. The group of EGFR mutation-positive patients (2 × Exon 18, 5 × Exon 19del, 1 × Exon 21) confirmed that neither smoking status nor age should be a reason for exclusion from the testing, although, also in our collective, the typical characteristics (female gender, neversmokers) predominated.Conclusions: These preliminary results allow valuable insights into our patient population. To some extent, this has important clinical impact, and stimulates improvements in quality of patient care.

Schinko 1, 2 ¹ Department of Pulmonary Medicine, General Hospital Linz, Kepler-University, Linz, Austria Background: Somatic mutations in epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) are detected in 12,6 % of the Austrian non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients [1] . The EGFR T790M Mutation located on Exon 20 is the most common mechanism of drug resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI) in EGFR-mutated NSCLC patients [2] . There is no documented clinical experience with the T790M Inhibitor in Austria.Methods: We administered AZD9291, a 3rd generation EGFR-TKI which is also active in tumours harbouring the T790M Mutation, to 4 patients who had disease progression after previous treatment with an EGFR TKI. We are provided with the EGFR inhibitor AZD9291 by AstraZeneca for patients without further treatment options (compassionate access), who had several lines of therapy. In two patients the T790M mutation was detected by re-biopsy of the tumor tissue (pleura effusion, supraclavicular lymph node) and in two patients by liquid biopsy. Blood samples were collected in EDTA Vacutainer tubes. Neutral buffered formalin solution was added immediately. DNA extraction was done with the DNA Sample Preparation Kit Roche®. Mutation testing was performed with the COBAS 4800 EGFR Mutation Test Kit ®. All 4 patients had already at least 2 lines of chemotherapy and 1 EGFR TKI. Treatment start with AZD9291 was between May and June 2015.Results: All 4 patients showed a clear clinical and radiographic improvement and 2 patients showed a complete remission after treatment with AZD9291. There are no reports of side effects after clinical application of AZD9291.Conclusions: AZD9291 was highly effective in our patients, while showing good tolerability. Therefore re-biopsy (tumor tissue or liquid biopsy) should be performed in clinical practice to detect the T790M Mutation. Liquid biopsy is more convenient to the patients and could replace the re-biopsy in clinical practice in the future.

Evaluation of adjuvant radiotherapy after bronchial sleeve resections for non small cell lung cancer Background: Bronchial sleeve resection in non small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is often required to avoid pneumonectomy in central tumors. Close resection margins are sometimes inevitable. To avoid local recurrence, adjuvant radiotherapy is frequently considered. But is it worth while?Methods: We retrospectively evaluated 199 consecutive patients after bronchial sleeve lobectomy of NSCLC. Complete resection was demonstrated for all of them by pathology. Indication for radiotherapy was a resection margin lesser 2 mm to the tumor or N2 disease. We formed two groups, group 1 received adjuvant radiotherapy and group 2 did not. Group 1 consisted of 64 patients with different tumor stages (IIB: n = 9; IIIA: n = 33; IIIB: n = 22) compared to group 2 consisting of 135 patients (IA + IB: n = 45; IIA + IIB: n = 45; IIIA: n = 28; IIIB: n = 9; IV: n = 8). Therefore the groups were not fully homogenous. The dosage of radiotherapy was 45-61 Gy.Results: Local recurrence was seen in 2 patients in group 1 (3.1 %) and in 2 patients in group 2 (1.5 %) (p = n.s.). Complications concerning the healing of the bronchial anastomosis were seen in 7.8 % (n = 5) in group 1 compared to 5.9 % (n = 8) in group 2 (p = n.s.). Distant metastases were observed in 51.5 % (n = 33) and 43.7 % (n = 8) respectively (p = n.s.). 2 and 5 years survival was 77 and 57 % in group 1 and 83 and 65 % in group 2 (p = n.s.). In stage IIIA survival was as well not significant in both groups, 60 % (n = 33) versus 71 % (n = 28). Difference in 5 year survival in patients free from N2 disease was 50 % (n = 14) in group 1 and 69.8 % (n = 90) in group 2 (p = n.s.).Conclusions: Adjuvant radiotherapy had no negative effect on healing of the bronchial anastomosis. Despite of adjuvant radiotherapy, the rate of local recurrence was slightly elevated. Especially in patients with close resection margins the positive effect of adjuvant radiotherapy is doubtful.

Clinical relevance of pharmacologic testing during right heart catheterization However, little is known about the acute effects of sildenafil and iloprost and their relationship to the effects for NO. Aims: 1. to assess the maximal vasodilatory response in patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH) and its relationship with baseline hemodynamics 2. to assess the change in pO2 during pharmacologic testing 3. to compare hemodynamic changes to NO, sildenafil and iloprost in different subgroups of PH (PAH and nonPAH-PH).

We analyzed retrospectively all patients undergoing right heart catheterization and pharmacologic testing with NO (15 ppm), sildenafil (50 mg) and iloprost (5 ug) between 2006 and 2014 in our center. Known NO responders were excluded. Hemodynamic responses were evaluated at baseline, during NO inhalation, 60 min after sildenafil intake and 5 min after inhalation with iloprost. Maximal vasodilatory response was defined as the change in mean pulmonary arterial pressure (mPAP) and pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) after iloprost inhalation as compared to baseline. Data are expressed as mean ± standard deviation.Results: We included n = 111 PH patients (age: 64 ± 14 yr, females/males: 62/49, meanPAP: 44.5 ± 12.2 mmHg, PVR: 8.3 ± 4.7 WU). Maximal vasodilatory response revealed a 20.2 ± 10.2 % decrease in mPAP and 28.3 ± 14.1 % decrease in PVR. This response was only moderately associated with baseline hemodynamics (r = −0.35, p = 0.0002 for mPAP; r = − 0.16, p = 0.03 for PVR). The change in pO2 was independent from baseline mPAP (r = 0.16, p = NS) and PVR (r = 0.11, p = NS). During NO inhalation, mPAP decreased by 4.5 ± 4.9 mmHg (p < 0.008) and showed a comparable response to sildenafil (-5.8 ± 4.4 mmHg, p < 0.0005) in the whole study population. The mPAP response to NO inhalation was strongly correlated with the response to sildenafil in PAH patients (n = 37, r = 0.67, p < 0.0001) and moderately in nonPAH-PH (n = 74, r = 0.34, p < 0.003). The same tendency was observed for iloprost as well.Conclusions: Maximum vasodilatory response in patients with PH was in average 20 % with large individual variability and was only moderately associated with baseline hemodynamics, challenging the concept of a vasoconstrictive disease turning into a "fixed" vasculopathy with disease progression.

Pulmonary rehabilitation: a tool to improve patients with COPD? Background: Pulmonary rehabilitation is a proven and recommended therapy in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Rehabilitation should last 6 to 12 weeks. Two different settings, for 6 weeks (Phase II) and 6 month (Phase III) respectively, are offered in the outpatient rehabilitation centre in Graz (ZAR Graz), consisting of a program according to the guidelines on pulmonary rehabilitation in adults.Methods: From 2011 to 2014, 72 patients underwent pulmonary rehabilitation, 38 with COPD, 16 with stable asthma and 18 suffering from other pulmonary diseases. Not all of them performed the scheduled mandatory 6 min walk test (6MWT) at beginning and the end of rehabilitation period.Results: 25/38 COPD patients could be evaluated by 6MWT at the beginning and the end of rehabilitation. Patients with COPD improved their walking distance at an average of 43.6 meters (− 54.5 to + 190 m). Phase II patients could improve more than Phase III patients (59.5 vs 9.7 meters leading from − 54.5 to 190 and from − 58.5 to 83.9 respectively).Taking regard on the MCID (minimal clinical important difference) witch is supposed to be more than 50 meters improvement in the 6 min walk test, only 9/17 patients with COPD during Phase II and only 1/8 after Phase III reached that goal.Conclusions: In our institution rehabilitation in patients with a variety of pulmonary diseases leads to a moderate benefit regarding the MCID criteria. This might be caused by respiratory infections with exacerbation of COPD during rehabilitation. Nevertheless they do improve their fitness and therefore manage their everyday work easier. As a consequence pulmonary rehabilitation should be offered to patients with COPD and is a treatment arm additionally to bronchodilatators and glucocorticoids.

Lung clearance index measurement coming of age Background: Lung clearance index (LCI) derived from multiple-breath washout (MBW) is an established proxy of small airways function in children with cystic fibrosis (CF). Yet, LCI measurements using a validated and available MBW setup and protocol have not been systematically studied in adults with prevalent chronic lung diseases.Methods: In a tertiary care center, 20 outpatients with asthma, 20 with COPD, and 14 with CF performed spirometry and nitrogen MBW using the ExhalyzerD. LCI was analysed at 2 MBW endpoints: at 1/40th (standard) and earlier at 1/20th (shortened) of starting nitrogen concentration. Outcomes were (i) prevalence of abnormal FEV1 and standard and shortened LCI (± 1.96 z-scores), (ii) agreement between LCIs and (iii) time savings achieved by the shortened protocol.Results: FEV1 and LCI were abnormal in 26/54 (48 %) and in 40/54 (74 %) patients, respectively. Stratifying into the disease groups asthma, COPD, and CF, FEV1 was abnormal in 3/20, 15/20, and 8/14; LCI2.5 was abnormal in 10/20, 17/20, 13/14, respectively. Agreement of standard and shortened LCI in categories normal vs. abnormal was excellent, Kappa = 0.81. Mean (SD) or average percent time savings were 280 (120) seconds (s) or 33 %, 540 (300) s or 43 %, 630 (440) s or 48 %.Conclusions: Despite normal spirometry, LCI detects abnormal lung function in 26 % of patients with obstructive lung diseases. Shortened LCI measurement is reliable and may increase feasibility in an outpatient setting due to considerable time savings.Background: DPIs are important inhalation devices in asthma bronchiale therapy. However, it is known from daily practice and several studies that DPIs are often incorrectly used leading to negative impact of therapeutic success. Aim of this NIS was to evaluate effectiveness and handling of Foster® NEXThaler®.Methods: A prospective, multicenter, non-interventional study (NIS) was conducted in pulmonary and general practices in Austria in 2014. Asthmatics treated with a fixcombination of extrafine 100 mg beclomethasone/6 mg formoterol delivered via NEXThaler® device (DPI) were monitored over 12 weeks (3 visits) . Lung function, symptom scores, exacerbations as well as satisfaction, adherence and tolerability were recorded. At baseline and last visit the patient check was performed to determine asthma control status (GINA check).Results: 175 patients (male 43 %, mean age 53 years) were analysed. Asthma control, lung function (PEF, FEV1 and FVC) and symptom scores improved significantly (p < 0.001), the exacerbation rate decreased significantly (p < 0.001) from 31 to 3.8 % after 12 weeks of treatment with Foster® NEXThaler®. A significant improvement of GINA score was seen in all patients (from 3.1 to 1.2 after 12 weeks; p < 0.001) and even in patients pretreated with ICS/LABA fixcombinations (p < 0.001). According to the physician's assessment 85.9 % of the patients were highly/very satisfied with the use of Foster® NEXThaler® and 97.4 % assessed the handling as very good/ good. Consequently, 93.3 % of the patients wished to continue with Foster® NEXThaler®. Three non-serious cases of adverse reactions were reported (dysphonia, tremor and pruritus).

The results showed effectiveness of treatment with Foster® Nexthaler®, improvement in asthma control, decreasing asthma symptoms and exacerbations and increasing of lung function parameters. Treatment was well tolerated and lead according to the physicians' opinion to very satisfied patients.
Are doctors familiar with the test characteristics of lung cancer screening?

Department of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine, Otto Wagner Hospital, Vienna, Austria Background: Screening with low-dose CT scan can prevent three deaths due to lung cancer among 1000 high-risk individuals. However, false-positive results and radiation exposure are relevant disadvantages deserving accurate consideration. Candidates for screening can only make an autonomous decision if doctors inform them correctly about the pros and cons of the method. Therefore, this study aims to evaluate, whether doctors understand the test characteristics of lung cancer screening.Methods: In a randomized trial, 556 doctors (members of the Austrian Respiratory Society) were invited to answer questions regarding lung cancer screening based on online case vignettes. Half of the participants were randomized to the group 'with solutions' and received the correct solutions in advance. The group 'without solutions' had to rely on prior knowledge or estimate. Primary endpoint was the between-groups difference in the estimated number of deaths preventable by screening. Secondary endpoints were the between-groups differences in prevalence of lung cancer, prevalence of suspicious results, sensitivity, specificity, positive-predictive value, and false negative rate. Estimations were also compared to actual values from the literature.Results: The response rate was 29 % in both groups (80 'without solutions' , 81, 'with solutions' , respectively). Reduction of number of deaths due to screening was overestimated six-fold (95%CI: 4-8) with no effect of group allocation. Providing the correct solutions to doctors had no systematic effect on their answers. Compared to actual values from the literature the prevalence of lung cancer was overestimated three-fold, while the prevalence of suspicious results, specificity, positive-predictive value, and false-negative rate were underestimated.Conclusions: Doctors poorly understand the test characteristics of lung cancer screening. Offering the correct solutions in advance did not improve the answers. Continuing education about lung cancer screening as well as interpretation of test characteristics might be simple remedies.
