back_matter.text: Moderate intensity continuous versus high intensity interval treadmill walking in patients with severe COPD: a pilot feasibility study Background: It has been shown that patients with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) perceive lower levels of dyspnea during interval cycling training compared to continuous cycling. In this pilot study we investigated if interval walking training is also feasible on a treadmill and if patients also show lower levels of dyspnea.Methods: 20 COPD patients (age: 62 ± 10 ys, FEV 1 : 37 ± 15 % pred.) were enrolled in this prospective, randomized study. All patients underwent a 3-week inpatient pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) program including a standardized exercise training with strength training and treadmill walking on 5 days per week. For the treadmill walking program patients were randomly assigned to either a moderate intense continuous group (MIC) walking at a speed of 60 % from mean baseline 6-minute walking test (6MWT) speed or a high intensity interval (HIT) group exercising at 120 % of mean 6MWT speed for 1 min alternating with 1 min of rest. Ratings for dyspnea (primary outcome) and leg fatigue on a 10-point Borg scale, heart rate and oxygen saturation were recorded during each session.Results: 6 MWD improved significantly (p < 0.001) in both groups without any significant between-group difference (MIC: 40 ± 41 m and HIT: 35 ± 19 m). Chair-rise-test improved significantly only in the HIT-group (− 2.5 ± 1.7 s, p = 0.003) but not in the MICgroup (− 1.3 ± 1.4 s, p = 0.051). Patients in the HIT-group showed the tendency of lower levels of dyspnea (Borg scale: 3.5 ± 1.0 versus 4.2 ± 1.4) and comparable leg fatigue (Borg scale: 2.6 ± 1.4 versus 2.7 ± 1.8) during exercise. Also mean oxygen saturation and heart rate were comparable between both exercise modalities.Conclusions: To our knowledge this pilot study was the first to investigate interval walking training on a treadmill in patients with severe COPD. It seems that MIC and HIT treadmill walking are both feasible exercise modalities. Adequately powered studies are needed to detect possible differences in physiological response and training effects. Background: PR following LTx can almost be seen as an established therapeutic modality. However, differences concerning the efficiency of pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) in patients with single (SLTx) or double (DLTx) lung transplantation have barely been studied yet.Methods: In a retrospective analysis (period: 1997-2013) 550 patients with COPD or interstitial lung diseases after LTx (SLTx: n = 212, FEV 1 55 ± 18 % pred., age: 58 ± 6 ys; DLTx: n = 338, FEV 1 70 ± 19 % pred., age: 53 ± 8 ys) were included. All patients underwent a standardized inpatient PR program of about 41 ± 18 days in average. Data of 6-minute walking distance (6MWD), health related quality of life (physical [PCS] and mental [MCS] component summary of the SF 36 questionnaire) and adverse events during PR have been registered and analyzed.Results: In SLTx patients, 6MWD increased from 267 ± 134 to 381 ± 120 (p < 0.001), PCS from 32 ± 9 to 39 ± 10 and MCS from 40 ± 17 to 48 ± 15 (p < 0.001 each). In DLTx patients, 6MWD increased from 284 ± 144 to 412 ± 126, PCS from 27 ± 11 to 35 ± 10 and MCS from 41 ± 16 to 50 ± 14 (p < 0.001 each). DLTx patients improved their 6MWD significantly (p = 0,045) more than SLTx patients. Benefits in HRQL were statistically comparable in patients with SLTx and DLTx Conclusions: These results show that patients benefit significantly and clinically relevant from a comprehensive PR program performed immediately after surgery. With regard to the improvements in HRQL, or frequency of complications during PR, there was no statistically difference. However exercise capacity improved significantly more in patients after DLTx.

Clinical impact of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs on the recurrence rate of pneumothoraces Background: Spontaneous pneumothorax is not uncommon. In 2013, 710 patients were diagnosed with spontaneous (tension) pneumothorax in Austria. There are many causes for recurrence and not all of them are identified yet. It has been proven that nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) lead to reduced efficacy of pleurodesis by attenuation of the inflamm-atory process. The effect of NSAID administration on the recurrence rate is barely investigatet yet. The aim of this study was to prove a correlation between the recurrence rate of spontaneous pneumothorax and the dose of NSAIDs.Methods: The quantity (mg), duration (days), substance as well as the time of ad-ministration (pre-or postoperative) of NSAIDs were analysed in 133 patients in this retrospective single-center study. The patients were divided into two goups. Patients that sustained a short-term recurrence of pneumothorax within 14 days were enrolled in the first goup (N = 25). The second group included all patients that had not sustained a recurrent pneumothorax during this period. (N = 108). Data were compared and analysed by the two-sample t-test (p ≤ 0.05).Results: No correlation between quantity, duration, substance, time of administration and short-term recurrence rate (within 14 days) could be detected.Conclusions: The results of this study could not justify the avoidance of NSAIDs perioperatively. Nevertheless, the influence of NSAIDs on the quality of pleurodesis should be considered and needs further investigation. Background: Complications in childhood pneumonia include pleural effusion, empyema, lung abscess, pneumatocele and necrotising pneumonia (NP), also named cavitatory pneumonia. NP is an uncommon complication but its incidence is increasing [Spencer et al. Paediatr Respir Rev 2014] .

Methods: We report on a 3-year-old girl with pneumonia and pleural effusion. The complicated disease course and management are presented.Results: The child presented with dyspnoe, hypoxia and diminished breath sounds over the left thorax and a red skin rash. Chest x-ray showed pneumonia in the left lower lobe and significant pleural fluid; laboratory values revealed leukopenia, hyponatremia and CRP 215 mg/l, PCT 310 ng/ml, IL -6 > 5000 pg/ml. Intravenous amoxicillin-clavulanate was started and a small-bore pigtail catheter inserted. In both drain fluid and a throat swab Streptococcus pyogenes was identified. After three days pleural drainage and urokinase instillation with clinical and laboratory improvement the girl again developed fever, and CRP and leucocytes increased (50.000/ml). Ultrasound and x-ray showed a large pleural effusion and opacification of the left hemithorax. Bronchoscopy excluded a foreign body, VATS was performed, a chest drain placed and antibiotics changed to clindamycin and ceftriaxon according to the antibiogram. After clinical and laboratory improvement again subfebrile temperatures and elevated CRP was detected. Chest CT showed loss of normal parenchymal architecture in parts of the left lung; BAL revealed no other pathogens. After a prolonged antibiotic course of 5 weeks a gradual and steady improvement could be achieved. A 4 weeks follow up showed excellent results.Conclusions: Management of NP includes conservative and surgical measures and may be difficult. Despite the severity of the illness, outcomes are excellent. Results: Of 18 published FSCA German and English FSN were found in 18/13 cases, respectively. FSN were clearly characterized as FSN in 12/9 or declaration of type of action in 13/9 cases, respectively. Product names, detailed information regarding FSCA and product malfunction were found in all German and English FSN. Lot numbers or other information for product characterization were available in 1/1 and 9/7 cases. Information on product related risks with previous use of affected devices was provided in 13/10 cases and in 17/13 cases manufacturers provided information to mitigate product related risks. Comments or descriptions playing down the risk were found in 3/2 cases. Typical types of product malfunction were software errors (6/4 cases), issues with electrical components (7/7 cases) and error in production (3/1 cases). Most frequent product related risks were erroneous ventilation or stop of therapy (5/3 cases) and fire hazard including burn (2/2 cases). Reported measures for risk mitigation were stop of use, product destruction or quarantine (4/3 cases), additional recommendations for use (2/2 cases) and others (8/7).Conclusions: Most FSN fulfil the MEDDEV criteria and include sufficient information on FSCA, type of product failure and corrective measures. However, due to their importance for reduction of product related risks in FSCA type and content of FSN should be further improved.

back_matter.text: The influence of inflammatory parameters and tumorous lymphatic vessel invasion on the postoperative survival in resected early stage nonsmall cell lung cancer Background: There is clinical evidence that inflammation accelerates tumor growth followed by reduced survival in patients with cancer. The aim of this study was done to evaluate the clinical impact of preoperatively measured inflammatory parameters and the incidence of lymphatic vessel invasion on the postoperative sur-vival in patients with resected non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) Stage I.Methods: For this retrospective data analysis, 741 patients who had undergone lung surgery due to lung cancer from 01.01.2003 to 31.12.2011 were assessed. However 156 patients met the inclusion criteria and were therefore considered for statistical evaluation.Results: 53 patients (34 %) showed preoperatively elevated CRP levels. Elevated leucocytes levels and hypoalbuminemia were detected in only 9 cases (5.8 %) . 110/156 patients (70.5 %) had GPS 0, 45 (28.8 %) had GPS 1 and only 1 patient had GPS2. The inflammatory parameters showed no statistical significance. The 5-year-overall survival (OS) was 74 %, 3-year and 1-year-OS were 79 and 95 %. However, 5-year-progression free survival (PFS) was 79 %, 3-year and 1-year-PFS yielded 84 and 96 %, respectively. A significant difference was detected between PFS and patients with lymphatic vessel invasion (p = 0.026), as well as CSS (Cancer specific survival) (p = 0.015). Lymphovascular tumor invasion is accompanied by a higher recurrence rate (p = 0.032), a significant lower progression free survival and a significant lower cancer specific survival.Conclusions: The expected prognostic impact of those inflammatory parameters on the postoperative survival of patients with curatively resected NSCLC stage I, could not be confirmed in this retrospective data analysis. On the other hand the histologically verified tumorous lymphatic vessel invasion has proven to serve as a prognostic independent parameter in this very collective and should be therefore taken into account when the decision concerning possible adjuvant therapy has to be made.

Torque Teno virus kinetics after lung transplantation and its association to immunosuppression schemes and to clinical complications Background: We have shown previously that the plasma DNA level of human Torque Teno virus (TTV), a virus which is widespread in the population and causes persistent DNAemia in the absence of any defined disease, is associated with immunosuppression in lung transplant recipients (LTRs). We now investigated the correlation of TTV DNA with different immunosuppressive schemes, and with the occurrence of clinical complications.Methods: Plasma TTV-DNA loads were analyzed at defined intervals within one year post transplantation by quantitative real-time PCR in 44 LTRs, receiving induction therapy with either Alemtuzumab (Campath) (n = 26) or with ATG (n = 12) or received no induction therapy (n = 6). The TTV load was further compared to clinical data.Results: The TTV-DNA load significantly increased in all cases post transplantation within the first 60-90 days and remained at high levels thereafter. The TTV-DNA load reached significantly higher levels in patients receiving induction therapy with Campath (p < 0.001). In 25 patients episodes of microbial infections occurred within the first year after transplantation. The patients' mean TTV DNA load prior to these episodes was significantly higher than that in 19 control patients without infections at the same time period (p = 0.002).Conclusions: Induction therapy with Campath seems to result in higher immunosuppression, reflected by TTV-DNA load post transplantation.
